summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing the Office of Chief Medical Examiner's (OCME) autopsy report on Jeffrey Epstein's death. It details the office's request for redactions before the report is released to Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, citing an ongoing criminal investigation and the sensitivity of included materials like FBI 302s and guard names.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Next of kin of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and the next of kin to whom the OCME plans to release the redacted autopsy report.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is the recipient of a report that contains information from an interview with Lt, a key MCC witness, though that specific information is requested to be redacted.

events.title: Planned submission of redactions to OCME
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office plans to provide their proposed redactions for the Epstein autopsy report to the Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME).

events.title: Email discussion on autopsy report redactions
events.description: SDNY prosecutors coordinate via email about redacting sensitive investigative materials from the OCME autopsy report before its release to Mark Epstein.

events.title: Discovery of handwritten note in Epstein's cell
events.description: The OCME autopsy report references a handwritten note found in Jeffrey Epstein's cell at the time of his death, described as a list of grievances about MCC conditions, not a suicide note.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office requested redactions to Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report before its release to his brother, Mark Epstein, to protect sensitive details of the ongoing criminal investigation.
Sensitive materials to be redacted included the names of prison guards under investigation, a draft FBI 302 of an interview with a key MCC witness (Lt), and other MCC documents.
A handwritten note found in Epstein's cell was described in the report as a list of grievances about MCC conditions (food, showers, bugs) and was assessed as not being a suicide note.
